title: Laser pen halts driverless cars
text:
Welcome to your preview of The Times Subscribe now Laser pen halts driverless cars A driverless car can be tricked into thinking that it is surrounded by obstacles, forcing it to stop STR/AFP/Getty Images Google+ 1 of 1 A driverless car can be tricked into thinking that it is surrounded by obstacles, forcing it to stop STR/AFP/Getty Images James Dean Technology Correspondent Published   8 2015 
Self-driving cars can be hacked and brought to a standstill using a laser pointer kit that costs less than £40, a security researcher has claimed. 
The device can trick a driverless car’s laser radar system into thinking that it is surrounded by obstacles, thereby immobilising it, he said. 
Driverless cars such as the bubble-shaped vehicle being developed by Google rely on roof-mounted laser radar, or lidar, to detect and avoid cars, pedestrians and other obstacles. The lidar units send out laser pulses that allow the car’s computer to build up a picture of the world around it.
